body: I have to concede that I won't have the bandwidth to follow up on this. Closing for now.
LGTM
+1 on sharing the design and plan, preferably on JIRA.
Noting here (as discussed on mailing list): The IMRU Examples and HelloREEF run successfully.
@markusweimer Do you have any other questions before continue the review?

This change fails 66 tests from `Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.DLL` on each of the three AppVeyor jobs. At a glance it looks like all tests which spawn evaluators fail. Please investigate the failures before considering merging this change.

AppVeyor passes for this change (at least 2 out of 3 jobs), so I can live with merging it :-) One of the things that needs fixing after this change is probably adding documentation for setting up standalone VS2017.
I completed a pass.
Pushed Fixes to address @jwang98052 's comments; waiting for the build, then will look into the build issues @tcNickolas .

After lots of experimentation with installing and removing VS2017 components, I still could not come up with the VS2017 setup that would build REEF.NET master without changes to the project file(s). I would suggest merging this PR and explicitly requiring Windows 10 SDK 10.0.15063.0. After that, we can open another issue in JIRA asking for a more general solution. @dougmsft @markusweimer what do you guys think?
This is my first ever PowerShell script, so please let me know if there are coding standards or conventions that I'm missing here.

This is what the output will look like: (run on master 70ca4d92c118accf51bb73c69d94cf8a8878a614)

Digging into the AppVeyor failures. There is a set of warnings about System.Reactive.Core start in at [Line 3230](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1639-master/job/6xjo8f3ul0uhfijd#L3230).

Here's a sample:
```17>C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\MSBuild\15.0\Bin\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(1964,5): warning MSB3245: Could not resolve this reference. Could not locate the assembly "System.Reactive.Core". Check to make sure the assembly exists on disk. If this reference is required by your code, you may get compilation errors. [C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.csproj]```

@tcNickolas I am a bit unfamiliar with the AppVeyor process. Could this be the cause of the test failure that we see?

**Update**: I may actually be able to reproduce these locally. I'll update this once I have clarity on this.
These test failures in the IMRU and KMeans  appear to be transient test failures as covered in REEF-1462
Transient KMeans failure.

AppVeyor is a model of building REEF and running tests on a fresh machine from scratch; it creates a virtual machine with some basic software installed, clones REEF enlistment and builds it (including packages download). It might be that this new package doesn't get loaded properly, but then wouldn't we get compilation errors on the code which uses this reference instead of successful compilation followed by test failures?

If you need to debug which packages AppVeyor downloads (or anything else that it does), you have to
1. Set up AppVeyor build for your clone of REEF repo, as described in https://github.com/apache/reef/blob/master/lang/cs/BUILD.md - this will speed up your debugging, as you'll be able to cancel jobs mid-test and not be blocked by builds of others' pull requests.
2. Edit https://github.com/apache/reef/blob/master/appveyor.yml , probably `build_script` section, to add a step like `dir .\lang\cs\packages` and see what is on the disk.

Unfortunately, we don't have a more straightforward access to AppVeyor VMs.
Now it is a transient IMU test failure.
This looks great! Any chance we can store the number of incompatibilities in a file and then fail the build if the number goes up?

Hi @tcNickolas ! Thanks for the pointers. These test failures are real and I see them locally. When I upgraded all the nugets, I forgot to `clean` the project before I ran `build`. I'm seeing these errors locally and investigating.

> I would suggest merging this PR and explicitly requiring Windows 10 SDK 10.0.15063.0.

What is improved by this PR if it doesn't make REEF.NET build on VS 2017?

Can we put this script to reef/dev or reef/bin folder? These are the folders where our build and test-related scripts reside, it's convenient to keep them all in one place. Especially if we want to run this script in AppVeyor eventually.

Speaking of running in AppVeyor, can you add it to https://github.com/apache/reef/blob/master/appveyor.yml? There is an `after_build` step in AppVeyor configuration which seems most appropriate. This way it would print the result before running tests, so failed tests wouldn't block compatibility check

@markusweimer At a glance this will 1) break in AppVeyor because it always builds from scratch and doesn't keep history, and 2) require that the reviewer runs build for master then build for pull request to get the correct value. There are some CI systems which allow to store information between consecutive builds (I think I've seen one for Cobertura when I was looking at Java tooling) but I don't see an easy way to set it up. Unless we write the result to some remote location accessible from all build workstations which would keep versioning and branch information... which stops being easy
@motus , will you review this and get it across the finish line? I'll step away then :)
LGTM, will merge

@tcNickolas, I was thinking of checking in the number of allowed warnings. That way, a PR that would add code that adds new warnings would have to change that line or file as well to pass the tests. And we can then make a decision in the discussion here on whether or not (more likely) we allow it.

@markusweimer the *only* purpose of this PR is to make REEF.NET build on VS2017. It's a one-line change to the build file. It does solve the build problem on my PC, though, as well as on our CI servers, so I would like to merge this PR if you do not mind.

Test failed:

System.NullReferenceException : Object reference not set to an instance of an object.

 at Org.Apache.REEF.Client.Tests.YarnClientTests.<TestGetApplications>d__3.MoveNext() in C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Client.Tests\YarnClientTests.cs:line 167
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)

@markusweimer I like the idea. But it will increase the number of merge conflicts (even if two pull requests change different projects, the total number of warnings can change in both, resulting in a conflict), which AppVeyor doesn't handle well (we don't get merge conflicts often these days but I think it just refuses to do the build). We have to think about this carefully, what other consequences it might have. 

For now I'll just be happy with the script running automatically in AppVeyor and showing the number of warnings.
Oh, I see. Yes, by all means, go ahead :)
Okay, let's go ahead and merge it for now. I will try setting up a new build machine as time permits and try to understand why current standalone VS 2017 environment works with 8.1 SDK.
Just pushed the change. @motus Thanks for the review!

I just pushed changes that fix these build issues. In brief, I had a silent error in the .csproj file for REEF.Tests/ that caused the build to use System.Reactive.Core 3.0.1 instead of 3.1.1 (I used a `${}` instead of `$()` to reference the SystemReactiveVersion variable).

There are 2 test failures here, but they work on my local machine, so I think they are transient -- one of them fails _sometimes_ on my laptop but will work when re-run.
Transient test failure in Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.Failure.TestEvaluatorWithActiveContextImmediatePoison
Those seem like transient failures. @tcNickolas do we have your blessing to merge?
I'll re-run the Yarn tests first.
Resolved
Yes, these are transient failures. Signing off from CI point of view (haven't looked into the change itself much)
Yarn tests pass! (HelloREEF and IMRU.Examples)

@acraghav Please make sure that with your changes the code still builds and passes the tests in all VS2013, VS2015 and VS2017. The current change fails build in 2013, as can be seen in AppVeyor build.

Also, your commit message says "closes #1320" but #1320 is a completely unrelated pull request. Please either keep the PR number empty or use the correct one.
I fixed the merge issues.
I finished initial pass. You might want to add some test cases to reach the new code path.
Transient test failure in 2013 build. 2015 and 2017 builds pass.

Here is the latest version. This
* Addresses the code issues that Markus brought up
* Moves it into `\bin`
* Adds an `after_build` step in AppVeyor that runs the script
* Creates all artifacts in the `\lang\cs\bin\x64\Debug\` directory
* Creates a file with the number of incompatibilities in `\lang\cs\bin\x64\Debug\ClrCompatibility\incompatibilities.txt`

Possible Issues:
* This script only targets `Debug` builds.
* Nothing is done with the incompatibilities file.
* The AppVeyor changes _were not tested_

@craig1583 After the second commit in this pull request AppVeyor build started to fail building in VS2015 and VS2017. Strangely, it looks like some problem building Java side during .NET build, but Travis built Java code successfully. Please investigate
It does print the results of the script execution in AppVeyor console, so from that point of view LGTM (not looked at the script itself).
LGTM will merge.

Each of the three AppVeyor jobs is failing 69 to 70 tests. Please investigate and fix the root cause of the failures before this pull request can be reviewed.

Do the tests pass for you locally if you clean everything, delete `bin` folder and build the project from scratch?
LGTM.
LGTM. I will test and merge it.

Travis CI fails. Please fix Checkstyle violations

    [ERROR] src/main/java/org/apache/reef/runtime/yarn/util/YarnConfigurationSetUp.java:[30,1] (extension) HideUtilityClassConstructor: Utility classes should not have a public or default constructor.

    [ERROR] src/main/java/org/apache/reef/runtime/yarn/util/YarnConfigurationSetUp.java:[33] (javadoc) JavadocStyle: First sentence should end with a period.

@tcNickolas A set of error messages start in [Line 619](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1662-master/job/bshi4yj2weqr8l5w#L619) saying it can't find protobuf 2.5.0.
How can I deal with this kind of problem?
`
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-antrun-plugin:1.7:run (generate-sources) on project reef-common: An Ant BuildException has occured: 2.5.0 expected, but protoc version was:
`
`
[ERROR] around Ant part ...<fail message="2.5.0 expected, but protoc version was: ${protoc.version}">... @ 7:77 in C:\projects\reef\lang\java\reef-common\target\antrun\build-main.xml
`

Edit: Oops, never mind, confused protobuf version with protoc version. We are supposed to be using 2.5.0. Don't have a guess for the cause then.

~~My guess is that we're using an earlier version of protobuf; pull request #1334 is going to update it to 2.1.0 but 2.5.0 is way beyond that. You have to figure out why your change requires 2.5.0 and remove that dependency~~

One option would be to create a file with a mixed-case name on HDFS, and see if we can access it correctly.  We have a bunch of unit tests that run on Hadoop when `REEF_TEST_YARN` environment variable is set, so it's OK to add one more.

**P.S.** Look at e.g. [UnmanagedAmTest](https://github.com/apache/reef/blob/master/lang/java/reef-runtime-yarn/src/test/java/org/apache/reef/runtime/yarn/driver/unmanaged/UnmanagedAmTest.java) to see how we use the JUnit `Assume` to run the test only when Hadoop testing is requested.

Also, you can give `GetUriPrefix()` method package access, and make sure your unit tests are in the same package. I would probably have unit tests for both such configurations (i.e. using `GerUriPrefix()` and accessing HDFS)
@tcNickolas It looks like the problem we encounter on AppVeyor is related to #1334. @craig1583 could you please check?
I modified the exception handling based on Julia feedback and now I am addressing Sergi's feedback.
Cool! Please feel free to ping me if you have questions. Also, please make sure that the tests pass on CI (they currently fail on Travis on all platforms)
@jwang98052 could you please close that PR? I forgot to set the PR number in the commit message
@motus It is closed. Thanks!

@motus OK, I will add the unit test. 
#1334 seems updating protobuf version on cs build. But in my case, the error occurs from java build. I tried to reproduce this error, but it passes all tests in my local environment.
LGTM, will merge.
Actually, did anyone validate this on YARN?
Not yet, Rogan was going to run this. Let's wait just to be on the safe side. I will sync up with him today.
@rogancarr, can you please sign off on this once you tested it? I'm happy to merge after that.
@motus Good suggestion. I thought about this way, now implemented. Please look at it again. Thanks!
I addressed all of you comments motus.

@motus I tested e2e on yarn with both file url set and unset. 
Just committed the change. Let's wait until AppVeyor completes.
Okay, I fixed all of the nits. Please review.
rebased
LGTM, will merge
Before considering to merge this, we should conclude the discussion over on JIRA whether or not we can just use Parquet.NET instead.
I still can't build this branch. I have a thread on the mailing list about this. If one of you could take a look at that, I would appreciate it. I'll investigate now.
Just saw it and responding now.

Talked to @singlis in person and worked through the issue. Looks like it was an issue with my Visual Studio 2017 setup. There were no changes in the commit that could have caused this error.

Testing now.

@motus Aren't you a bit concerned about AppVeyor build failing on all branches for this change? Should at least do a rebuild to check whether the failure is a transient problem with AppVeyor or a real issue before merging
Oops, just noticed the CI status. @jwang98052 could you please take a look? Thanks!
There are conflicts now too - let me merge those and re-submit.
Conflicts have been resolved.
Conflicts are now resolved, need confirmation from Rogan.

HelloREEF and IMRU.Examples run on Yarn and show a Final Status of Success.

@markusweimer Any other tests that you'd like to run? And do we need any specific lines from the log files just to make sure?

There is a failed CI test  FailTaskTest.testFailTaskStop:86->failOn:52 expected:<FAILED> but was:<COMPLETED>. 
Looks irrelevant to the change. I cannot repro from local. 

However, .Net release build is broken in master. I just created REEF-1833 for it. 

@tcNickolas is right, we should be really careful to make sure CI and AppVeyor build and test pass before the merge. If there is any test failures, they must be known issues.
The appveyor tests failed due to a nuget timeout. Is there a way to restart the build?
All of the new issues have been addressed.

@jwang98052 `FailTaskTest.testFailTaskStop` failure looks like a race condition. Please open a JIRA issue and document it. Indeed, it is not relevant to this PR. As for the AppVeyor failures, look what's going on there. We used to have test failures there due to AppVeyor inability to fetch some nugets (network issue?). There were other build issues described by @dougmsft - those should be fixed in current master. You can try to merge in current master and see what happens on AppVeyor.
We have seen this failure of `FailTaskTest` before, it was mentioned in comments https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1668 so it's not a new occurrence.
@rogancarr: Can you please fix the merge conflicts? That should also kick off another build.
I just resolved them.
AppVeyor shows both VS 2013 and VS2015 didn't really build. Did we check the reason before the merge?

So before the merge, VS2015 failed to download a nuget package which caused the rest of the build to fail. I did not look at the cause for VS2013. 

With the current run however:
VS2013 timed out after 90 minutes. The build log just stops.
VS2015 ran but has an error ant exception - which may look valid:
    24>Build:
         [ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-antrun-plugin:1.7:run (generate-sources) on project reef-common: An Ant BuildException has occured: 2.5.0 expected, but protoc version was:
         [ERROR] around Ant part ...<fail message="2.5.0 expected, but protoc version was: ${protoc.version}">... @ 7:77 in C:\projects\reef\lang\java\reef-common\target\antrun\build-main.xml

If this is accepted, I will file a new issue to implement a CoreCLR-compatible performance monitoring solution. (Although it appears that there is no cross-platform way to do this yet.)

@dougmsft I've made a few minor fixes to your `ProtocolSerializer`. Most importantly, we have stricter types in the `Read()` method (although I was not able to do so for the internal delegates etc.). Could you please review? Thank you!
Will try it on my PC now while AppVeyor tests run.

As far as I can tell, this looks like an intermittent failure for VS2015. It fails when checking the version of protoc - protoc is installed via the appveyor-install-dependencies script and the build shows it downloading 100%. The version check just simply executes protoc with the --version parameter and captures std out looking for version 2.5.0.

My change does not affect any of this.  I will try to kick the build here.
You might need to rebase then push in to the branch to trigger AppVeyor build based on the latest.
Looks like the build is failing due to time outs.
All tests (except some functional ones) pass on my PC. @singlis could you please rebase your commits and resolve the conflicts?
